members.name: National Drought and Flood Recovery Regions
NSW Combined Drought Indicator
members.description:
The NSW Combined Drought Indicator (CDI) is developed by the NSW Department of Primary Industries (DPI), and it provides detailed seasonal conditions information for NSW primary producers. This data will be used to inform policy and Government responses to changing seasonal conditions, including drought. According to the NSW DPI, the CDI is not used to determine the eligibility for assistance measures offered by the NSW Government.

The CDI comprises of four indicators:

  • Rainfall Index (RI)
  • Soil Water Index (SWI)
  • Plan Growth Index (PGI)
  • Drought Direction Index (DDI)

More information on the CDI and its indicators, can be found here: https://edis.dpi.nsw.gov.au/

members.name: Monthly rainfall 1910-2017
members.description:
Data service visualisation of high resolution monthly rainfall gridded data from 1910 onwards provided by the Bureau of Meteorology. The grids show the rainfall values across Australia in the form of two-dimensional array data. The data extends from 1910 onwards. North Bounding Latitude: -9.975; South Bounding Latitude: -44.525; East Bounding Longitude: 156.275; West Bounding Longitude: 111.975.
The analysis (grids) used for the service production are computer generated using a sophisticated analysis technique. It incorporates an optimised Barnes successive correction technique that applies a weighted averaging process to the station data. Topographical information is included by the use of rainfall ratio (actual rainfall divided by monthly average) in the analysis process. On the maps each grid-point represents a rectangular area with sides 0.05⁰ latitude by 0.05⁰ longitude (approximately 5km by 5km). The size of the grids is limited by the data density across Australia. This grid-point analysis technique provides an objective average for each grid square and enables useful estimates in data-sparse areas such as central Australia. However, in data-rich areas such as southeast Australia or in regions with strong gradients, “data smoothing” will occur resulting in grid-point values that may differ slightly from the exact rainfall amount measured at the contributing stations.
The observational (station) data on which the analyses were based have an associated accuracy of the order of 0.01 degrees (approximately 1km) or better. Note: The gridded data shown over ocean areas are statistical artefacts of the analysis scheme and not actual rainfall values

members.name: National Holdings
members.description:
The FMD Scheme assists primary producers to deal more effectively with fluctuations in cash flows. It is designed to increase the self-reliance of Australian primary producers by helping them manage their financial risk and meet their business costs in low-income years by building up cash reserves.

The scheme allows eligible primary producers to set aside pre-tax income from primary production in years of high income, which they can draw on in future years when they need it, such as for restocking or replanting when conditions start to improve.

Income deposited into an FMD account is tax deductible in the financial year the deposit is made. It becomes taxable income in the financial year in which it is withdrawn.

Financial institutions offering FMDs are required to report details of the FMDs they hold at the end of a month to the Department of Agriculture and Water Resources. Reports must be submitted by close of business on the 10th calendar day of the following month. The department endeavours to release a summary of these statistics by the 15th calendar day of each month. The department cannot prepare a summary of the statistics until it has received returns from all relevant financial institutions.

More information is available at http://www.agriculture.gov.au/ag-farm-food/drought/assistance/fmd/statistics

members.name: Number of Farmers across Australia by local governments authorities
members.description:
2015-16 agricultural commodity estimates for Australia’s Local Government Areas (LGA) were produced by concording the previously released Statistical Area level 2 (SA2) estimates to LGA regions, using the ABS produced Statistical Area Level 2 2011 to Local Government Area 2016 area weighted correspondence.

In the LGA estimates, there are instances where a business count exists but its related estimated value is zero, and vice versa.

Where data cells in the original SA2 estimates had been suppressed due to confidentialisation, the contents of the data cells were replaced with zeros prior to the concordance of the data.

Further information on correspondences and the mathematical methods of reassigning data from one geographic region to another is available in the Information Paper: “Converting Data to the Australian Statistical Geography Standard, 2012 (cat. no. 1216.0.55.004)”

Further information can be found at: http://www.abs.gov.au/AUSSTATS/abs@.nsf/Lookup/7121.0Main+Features12015-16?OpenDocument and http://www.abs.gov.au/AUSSTATS/subscriber.nsf/log?openagent&7121do011_201516.csv&7121.0&Data%20Cubes&A021AC4C9395F561CA2583350013B803&0&2015-16&30.10.2018&Previous

members.name: Farm Household Allowance current demand against States and Territories
members.description:
A payment for farming families in financial hardship. Eligible to:
  • a farmer who spends a major part of your time and capital working on the farm
  • the partner of a farmer who spends a major part of your time and capital working on the farm
  • meets the income and assets test limits
  • meets mutual obligation requirements
Data is provided for each state and territory on:
  1. number of current clients - the client’s claim was approved, the client is currently receiving payment and being cased managed by the Department of Human Services
  2. number of granted clients - the client’s claim was approved at any point in time

More information available at http://www.agriculture.gov.au/ag-farm-food/drought/assistance/farm-household-allowance/dashboard

members.name: Farm Household Case Officers
members.description:
As part of the Farm Household Allowance recipients are required to meet every three months to talk about progress in achieving mutual obligations. This can be in person or over the phone.

More details are available at https://www.humanservices.gov.au/individuals/services/centrelink/farm-household-allowance

members.name: Private boarding schools
members.description:
Boarding schools play a unique role in the provision of schooling for families in special circumstances, such as those in Australia’s rural and remote communities, or those living and working overseas. The private school sector provides boarding facilities through approximately 150 schools for almost 16,200 students.

Further information can be found at: https://isca.edu.au/about-independent-schools/boarding-schools/ and http://www.boarding.org.au/find-a-school

Further information can be found at: http://www.boarding.org.au/find-a-school

members.name: Root zone soil moisture, month-to-date
members.description:
Root Zone Soil Moisture is the sum of water in the AWRA-L Upper and Lower soil layers and represents the percentage of available water content in the top 1 m of the soil profile. The maximum storage within the soil layer is calculated from the depth of the soil and the relative soil water storage capacity. The soil properties that control the storage of water are derived from the continental scale mapping within Australian Soil Resources Information System (Johnston et al., 2003). The relative available water capacity of the soil layer is derived from ASRIS information as the available water capacity of a layer divided by its thickness. Pedotransfer functions are used to relate soil hydraulic properties to soil textural class. Soil drainage and moisture dynamics are then based on water balance considerations for each soil layer. The shallow and deep rooted vegetation can both draw on this combined layer.

Actual soil moisture grids estimate the percentage of available water content rather than total soil water volume. Relative soil moisture grids, like the other grids, represent the long term deciles.

members.name: Rural Adversity Mental Health Program (RAMHP)
members.description:
The Rural Adversity Mental Health Program (RAMHP) is a state-wide program funded by the NSW Ministry of Health, that links rural people to the help they need. RAMHP is managed by the Centre for Rural and Remote Mental Health (CRRMH), in partnership with each of the rural NSW Local Health Districts.

Website: http://www.ramhp.com.au/

members.name: Rural Financial Counsellors Services offices
members.description:
Rural financial counsellors provide support for farmer to make the right business decisions. They help farmers:
  • identify financial and business options
  • develop an action plan
  • negotiate with lenders
  • apply for Farm Household Allowance.

Rural financial counsellors do not give family, emotional or social counselling or financial advice.

They can give you referrals to other professional services. This includes accountants, agricultural advisors, education, or counselling.

Call 1800 686 175. They will refer you to your nearest RFCS office.

http://www.agriculture.gov.au/ag-farm-food/drought/assistance/rural-financial-counselling-service

members.name: Annual minimum temperature 1910-2017
members.description:
Data service visualisation of high resolution annual minimum temperature gridded datasets from 1910 onwards provided by the Bureau of Meteorology. The grids show the minimum temperatures values across Australia in the form of two-dimensional array data. The data extends from 1910 onwards. North Bounding Latitude: -9.975; South Bounding Latitude: -44.525; East Bounding Longitude: 156.275; West Bounding Longitude: 111.975.

The analyses (grids) are computer generated using a sophisticated analysis technique. It incorporates an optimised Barnes successive correction technique that applies a weighted averaging process to the station data. Topographical information is included in the use of anomalies (departures from average) in the analysis process. On the maps each grid-point represents an approximately square area with sides of about 5km (0.05 degrees). The size of the grids is limited by the data density across Australia.

The grid-point analysis technique provides an objective average for each grid square and enables useful estimates in data-sparse areas such as central Australia, However, in data-rich areas such as southeast Australia or in regions with strong gradients, “data smoothing” will occur resulting in grid-point values that may differ slightly from the exact temperature measured at contributing stations.

The observational (station) data on which the analyses were based have an associated accuracy of the order of 0.01 degrees (approximately 1km) or better.

Note: The gridded data shown over ocean areas are statistical artefacts of the analysis scheme and not actual temperature values.

members.name: Monthly minimum temperature 1910-2017
members.description:
Data service visualisation of high resolution monthly minimum temperature gridded datasets from 1910 onwards provided by the Bureau of Meteorology. The grids show the minimum temperatures values across Australia in the form of two-dimensional array data. The data extends from 1910 onwards. North Bounding Latitude: -9.975; South Bounding Latitude: -44.525; East Bounding Longitude: 156.275; West Bounding Longitude: 111.975.
Gridded datasets were generated using a spline interpolated analysis. The grid point resolution of the data is 0.05 degrees (approx. 5km). All available temperature stations were used in the analyses, and the input station data underwent standard quality control. The observational (station) data on which the analyses were based have an associated accuracy of the order of 0.01 degrees (approximately 1km) or better. Note: The gridded data shown over ocean areas are statistical artefacts of the analysis scheme and not actual temperature values.

members.name: National Drought and Flood Recovery Regions
Root zone soil moisture, month-to-date
members.description:
Root Zone Soil Moisture is the sum of water in the AWRA-L Upper and Lower soil layers and represents the percentage of available water content in the top 1 m of the soil profile. The maximum storage within the soil layer is calculated from the depth of the soil and the relative soil water storage capacity. The soil properties that control the storage of water are derived from the continental scale mapping within Australian Soil Resources Information System (Johnston et al., 2003). The relative available water capacity of the soil layer is derived from ASRIS information as the available water capacity of a layer divided by its thickness. Pedotransfer functions are used to relate soil hydraulic properties to soil textural class. Soil drainage and moisture dynamics are then based on water balance considerations for each soil layer. The shallow and deep rooted vegetation can both draw on this combined layer.

Actual soil moisture grids estimate the percentage of available water content rather than total soil water volume. Relative soil moisture grids, like the other grids, represent the long term deciles.

members.name: Rainfall, month-to-date
members.description: Daily precipitation grids are produced by the Bureau from approximately 6,500 rain gauge stations and interpolated to a 0.05 degree (approximately 5 x 5 km) national grid (Jones et al. 2009). Precipitation is an input into the AWRA-L model. The estimates are subject to approximations associated with interpolating observation point data to a national grid detailed in Jones et al. (2009). The precipitation input to the AWRA-L model are the near real time daily grids available at www.bom.gov.au/climate/maps. The monthly and annual precipitation is simply an aggregation of the near real time daily grids input to the AWRA-L model. Monthly grids that include additional rain gauge stations and rainfall observations (that are not available in near real time) can be found at www.bom.gov.au/climate/maps

members.name: Climate Guide Regions
members.description: The Regional Weather and Climate Guides project is part of the Australian Government’s Drought Assistance Package, announced by Minister for Drought David Littleproud on 19 August 2018. The project aims to improve the resilience of farming businesses by providing localised facts about the likelihood, severity and duration of key weather variables in regions across the country. The weather and climate information will be delivered through a set of guides corresponding to Australia's Natural Resource Management regions. The project is a collaboration between the Bureau of Meteorology, the CSIRO and FarmLink Research. The guides have been developed in collaboration with representatives from each NRM region to ensure the information is tailored to the needs of local farmers and agribusinesses.

members.name: Bureau of Meteorology - historical rainfall and temperature
Monthly rainfall 1910-2017
members.description:
Data service visualisation of high resolution monthly rainfall gridded data from 1910 onwards provided by the Bureau of Meteorology. The grids show the rainfall values across Australia in the form of two-dimensional array data. The data extends from 1910 onwards. North Bounding Latitude: -9.975; South Bounding Latitude: -44.525; East Bounding Longitude: 156.275; West Bounding Longitude: 111.975.
The analysis (grids) used for the service production are computer generated using a sophisticated analysis technique. It incorporates an optimised Barnes successive correction technique that applies a weighted averaging process to the station data. Topographical information is included by the use of rainfall ratio (actual rainfall divided by monthly average) in the analysis process. On the maps each grid-point represents a rectangular area with sides 0.05⁰ latitude by 0.05⁰ longitude (approximately 5km by 5km). The size of the grids is limited by the data density across Australia. This grid-point analysis technique provides an objective average for each grid square and enables useful estimates in data-sparse areas such as central Australia. However, in data-rich areas such as southeast Australia or in regions with strong gradients, “data smoothing” will occur resulting in grid-point values that may differ slightly from the exact rainfall amount measured at the contributing stations.
The observational (station) data on which the analyses were based have an associated accuracy of the order of 0.01 degrees (approximately 1km) or better. Note: The gridded data shown over ocean areas are statistical artefacts of the analysis scheme and not actual rainfall values

Data service visualisation of high resolution annual minimum temperature gridded datasets from 1910 onwards provided by the Bureau of Meteorology. The analyses (grids) are computer generated using a sophisticated analysis technique. It incorporates an optimised Barnes successive correction technique that applies a weighted averaging process to the station data. The observational (station) data on which the analyses were based have an associated accuracy of the order of 0.01 degrees (approximately 1km) or better.

Note: The gridded data shown over ocean areas are statistical artefacts of the analysis scheme and not actual temperature values.

members.name: Cyclone Seroja DRFA Activated LGAs April 2021
North and Far North Queensland 2019 Monsoon Trough Flood Affected LGAs
NSW and Southern QLD Flood DRFA Activated LGAs March 2021
Drought Communities Program eligible councils
members.description:
The Drought Communities Programme (DCP) Extension supports communities in the most drought-affected regions of Australia, funding local councils to complete local infrastructure and other drought relief projects.

As at 28 January 2020, 180 Councils have access to $301 million in funding providing an economic stimulus, creating jobs and supporting local communities.

The Drought Communities Programme Extension is being administered through the Business Grants Hub at the Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources.

Information about the DCP Extension, including a list of eligible councils, the program guidelines and application process is available at [www.business.gov.au/dcp](https://www.business.gov.au/dcp) or call 13 28 46.

members.name: ABARES Drought Risk by Farm Profit
members.description:
This layer displays the percentage of drought risk by Farm Profit by ABARES AAGIS (Australian Agricultural and Grazing Industry Survey) regions as determined by Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and Sciences.

Average farm profit drought risk has increased in recent years, due to an increase in drought sensitivity within the livestock sector. This largely reflects the impact of an extended run of poor conditions in many livestock farming areas since 2015-16, which has led to reductions in beef cattle and sheep stocking rates, and to hay and grain holdings which, at least in the short-run, increases the drought risk faced by these farms (Hughes et al. 2020). Despite these trends, household income drought risk has remained relatively stable overtime, due largely to an increase in average farm size, which reduces the likelihood of low farm household incomes (see Hughes et al. 2020).

members.name: ABARES Drought Risk by Household Income
National Holdings
members.description:
The FMD Scheme assists primary producers to deal more effectively with fluctuations in cash flows. It is designed to increase the self-reliance of Australian primary producers by helping them manage their financial risk and meet their business costs in low-income years by building up cash reserves.

The scheme allows eligible primary producers to set aside pre-tax income from primary production in years of high income, which they can draw on in future years when they need it, such as for restocking or replanting when conditions start to improve.

Income deposited into an FMD account is tax deductible in the financial year the deposit is made. It becomes taxable income in the financial year in which it is withdrawn.

Financial institutions offering FMDs are required to report details of the FMDs they hold at the end of a month to the Department of Agriculture and Water Resources. Reports must be submitted by close of business on the 10th calendar day of the following month. The department endeavours to release a summary of these statistics by the 15th calendar day of each month. The department cannot prepare a summary of the statistics until it has received returns from all relevant financial institutions.

More information is available at http://www.agriculture.gov.au/ag-farm-food/drought/assistance/fmd/statistics

members.name: Industry Holdings per state and territory
members.description:
The FMD Scheme assists primary producers to deal more effectively with fluctuations in cash flows. It is designed to increase the self-reliance of Australian primary producers by helping them manage their financial risk and meet their business costs in low-income years by building up cash reserves.

The scheme allows eligible primary producers to set aside pre-tax income from primary production in years of high income, which they can draw on in future years when they need it, such as for restocking or replanting when conditions start to improve.

This data provides a break down on total FMD holdings across different agricultural sectors

More information is available at http://www.agriculture.gov.au/ag-farm-food/drought/assistance/fmd/statistics

members.name: Number of Farmers across Australia by local governments authorities
members.description:
2015-16 agricultural commodity estimates for Australia’s Local Government Areas (LGA) were produced by concording the previously released Statistical Area level 2 (SA2) estimates to LGA regions, using the ABS produced Statistical Area Level 2 2011 to Local Government Area 2016 area weighted correspondence.

In the LGA estimates, there are instances where a business count exists but its related estimated value is zero, and vice versa.

Where data cells in the original SA2 estimates had been suppressed due to confidentialisation, the contents of the data cells were replaced with zeros prior to the concordance of the data.

Further information on correspondences and the mathematical methods of reassigning data from one geographic region to another is available in the Information Paper: “Converting Data to the Australian Statistical Geography Standard, 2012 (cat. no. 1216.0.55.004)”

Further information can be found at: http://www.abs.gov.au/AUSSTATS/abs@.nsf/Lookup/7121.0Main+Features12015-16?OpenDocument and http://www.abs.gov.au/AUSSTATS/subscriber.nsf/log?openagent&7121do011_201516.csv&7121.0&Data%20Cubes&A021AC4C9395F561CA2583350013B803&0&2015-16&30.10.2018&Previous

members.name: Centrelink Mobile Service Centre locations over time
members.description:
Centrelink operates a Mobile Service Centre where staff are able to travel across rural and regional areas to help people with services and payments.

More information is available at https://www.humanservices.gov.au/individuals/services/centrelink/mobile-service-centres

members.name: Farm Household Allowance current demand against States and Territories
members.description:
A payment for farming families in financial hardship. Eligible to:
  • a farmer who spends a major part of your time and capital working on the farm
  • the partner of a farmer who spends a major part of your time and capital working on the farm
  • meets the income and assets test limits
  • meets mutual obligation requirements
Data is provided for each state and territory on:
  1. number of current clients - the client’s claim was approved, the client is currently receiving payment and being cased managed by the Department of Human Services
  2. number of granted clients - the client’s claim was approved at any point in time

More information available at http://www.agriculture.gov.au/ag-farm-food/drought/assistance/farm-household-allowance/dashboard

members.name: Farm Household Case Officers
members.description:
As part of the Farm Household Allowance recipients are required to meet every three months to talk about progress in achieving mutual obligations. This can be in person or over the phone.

More details are available at https://www.humanservices.gov.au/individuals/services/centrelink/farm-household-allowance

members.name: Private boarding schools
members.description:
Boarding schools play a unique role in the provision of schooling for families in special circumstances, such as those in Australia’s rural and remote communities, or those living and working overseas. The private school sector provides boarding facilities through approximately 150 schools for almost 16,200 students.

Further information can be found at: https://isca.edu.au/about-independent-schools/boarding-schools/ and http://www.boarding.org.au/find-a-school

members.name: Public boarding schools
members.description:
Some state governments fund public boarding schools and hostels for students to attend in regional areas.   Further information can be found on State Government Department of Education websites.

Further information can be found at: http://www.boarding.org.au/find-a-school

members.name: Victorian Local Government Area Stage 4 Lockdown 2 August 2020
Medicare Offices
members.id: Root Group/National Data Sets/Social and Economic/Medicare Offices

members.name: General Practitioners (GPs)
members.description:
A general practitioner (GP) is a doctor who is also qualified in general medical practice. GPs are often the first point of contact for someone, of any age, who feels sick or has a health concern. They treat a wide range of medical conditions and health issues.

A GP may also undertake further education in specific areas such as mental health.

This data has been sourced from the National Health Services Directory. The data is self-authored location information only.

Further information can be found at: https://about.healthdirect.gov.au/national-health-services-directory

members.name: Headspace Centres
members.description: Headspace centres offer anyone aged between 12 and 25 years a single entry point to friendly primary care that includes early intervention services and support for physical and mental wellbeing.  Headspace centres can be found at https://headspace.org.au/headspace-centres/

members.name: Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) mental health data
members.description:
Mental health services are provided under the MBS by GPs, psychiatrists, psychologists and other allied health professionals. Mental health services are identified by specific MBS item numbers that are used by health professionals for billing purposes.

In terms of overall significance, MBS-subsidised mental health care accounts for approximately 80% of all Australians who consult a health practitioner for mental health assistance.

Regions with low values have been suppressed - this is to prevent potential re-identification of individuals. Data for any SA3-level record has been suppressed where either the patient count is 5 or less; or more than 85% of services were provided by a sole provider, or more than 90% was provided by two providers.

Further information can be found at: http://www.health.gov.au/mentalhealth-betteraccess

members.name: Primary Health Networks (PHN) mental health data
members.description:
PHNs were established in 2015 in each of 31 regions, replacing the former Medicare Locals entities, and covering all Australia. Commencing in 2016 17, significant funding was allocated to PHNs to commission a range of mental health services, designed to target hard to reach and other populations that are not well serviced by the MBS fee-for-service system.

Regions with low values have been suppressed - this is to prevent potential re-identification of individuals. Data for any SA3-level record has been suppressed where the patient count is 5 or less. No suppression has been applied based on counts of providers due to the inability to uniquely identify providers in these collections.

Further information can be found at: http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/PHN-Home

members.name: Psychologists
members.description:
A psychologist is a professional trained in the science of how people think, feel, behave and learn.

Most psychologists provide assessment and therapy to clients, help facilitate organisational or social change, conduct psychological research, or administer psychological tests to individuals or groups.

This data has been sourced from the National Health Services Directory. The data is self-authored location information only.

Further information can be found at: https://about.healthdirect.gov.au/national-health-services-directory

members.name: Rural Adversity Mental Health Program (RAMHP)
members.description:
The Rural Adversity Mental Health Program (RAMHP) is a state-wide program funded by the NSW Ministry of Health, that links rural people to the help they need. RAMHP is managed by the Centre for Rural and Remote Mental Health (CRRMH), in partnership with each of the rural NSW Local Health Districts.

Website: http://www.ramhp.com.au/

members.name: Social Workers
members.description:
The social work profession in Australia is broad and diverse but consistent to all practice is a commitment to human rights and social justice. Social workers work with individuals, families, groups and communities in the context of their physical, social and cultural environments, their past and current experiences, and their cultural and belief systems.

In all contexts, social workers maintain a dual focus on both assisting with and improving human wellbeing and identifying and addressing any external issues (known as system or structural issues) that may impact on wellbeing or may create inequality, injustice and discrimination.

Social workers may undertake roles in casework, counselling, advocacy, community engagement and development and social action to address issues at both the personal and social level. Social workers also work in areas such as policy development, education and research particularly around issues of social justice, disadvantage and the marginalisation of people in their communities or in society.

This data has been sourced from the National Health Services Directory. The data is self-authored location information only.

Further information can be found at: https://about.healthdirect.gov.au/national-health-services-directory

members.name: NSW Combined Drought Indicator
members.description:
The NSW Combined Drought Indicator (CDI) is developed by the NSW Department of Primary Industries (DPI), and it provides detailed seasonal conditions information for NSW primary producers. This data will be used to inform policy and Government responses to changing seasonal conditions, including drought. According to the NSW DPI, the CDI is not used to determine the eligibility for assistance measures offered by the NSW Government.

The CDI comprises of four indicators:

  • Rainfall Index (RI)
  • Soil Water Index (SWI)
  • Plan Growth Index (PGI)
  • Drought Direction Index (DDI)

More information on the CDI and its indicators, can be found here: https://edis.dpi.nsw.gov.au/

members.name: National Drought and Flood Recovery Regions
Rural Financial Counsellors Services offices
members.description:
Rural financial counsellors provide support for farmer to make the right business decisions. They help farmers:
  • identify financial and business options
  • develop an action plan
  • negotiate with lenders
  • apply for Farm Household Allowance.

Rural financial counsellors do not give family, emotional or social counselling or financial advice.

They can give you referrals to other professional services. This includes accountants, agricultural advisors, education, or counselling.

Call 1800 686 175. They will refer you to your nearest RFCS office.

http://www.agriculture.gov.au/ag-farm-food/drought/assistance/rural-financial-counselling-service

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people
members.description: The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population comprises people who are of Aboriginal origin, Torres Strait Islander origin or both Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander origin. There is significant volatility in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Census counts and the quality of data on births, deaths and migration of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander persons. These figures should be treated as indicative only.

info.name: Source
info.content: Australian Bureau of Statistics – Regional Statistics by LGA 2017 http://stat.data.abs.gov.au/Index.aspx

members.name: Age profile
members.description: This indicator provides a guide to the differences in the age makeup of LGAs in 2018.

members.name: Average household size
members.description: The indicator is based on the number of persons in occupied private dwellings (place of usual residence), rather than being based only on a family unit.

members.name: Businesses entry active exit
members.description: The new business entry rate measures the rate at which businesses are entering the market. The business exit rate measures the rate at which businesses are exiting the market.

members.name: Dwellings with an internet connection
members.description:
This indicator provides a measure of the proportion of dwellings from which internet can be accessed. This includes access through an ADSL, fibre, cable or wireless connection to the dwelling, as well as other means such as 3G or 4G mobile broadband. Some dwellings may have access to an internet connection even if it is not paid for by the household, for example those who have an internet connection provided by their employer.

This indicator includes any type of internet connection that can be accessed from the dwelling via any method (computers, mobile or smart phones, gaming consoles, etc.)

members.name: Employed persons
members.description: This indicator is based on the usual residence of the employed person and not the location at which they work.

members.name: Estimated resident population
members.description: The estimated resident population refers to the number of usual residents in a region.

members.name: Household stress
members.description: This indicator shows the percentage households in the region with mortgage repayments or rent greater than or equal to 30% of household income.

info.name: Source
info.content: Australian Bureau of Statistics – Regional Statistics by LGA 2017 http://stat.data.abs.gov.au/Index.aspx

members.name: Industry of employment
members.description: A person’s industry of employment relates to the activities undertaken by the business for which they work. Where a person works in more than one job, the industry classification relates to their main job – the one in which they usually work the most hours. Data is presented as the percentage of the population residing in the LGA employed by an industry.

info.name: Source
info.content: Australian Bureau of Statistics – Regional Statistics by LGA 2017 http://stat.data.abs.gov.au/Index.aspx

members.name: Insolvencies
members.description: The business and non-business personal insolvency statistics include personal insolvencies and not corporate insolvencies. Every debtor who becomes bankrupt or proposes a debt agreement or personal insolvency agreement is required to lodge a completed statement of affairs form with Australian Financial Security Authority.

info.name: Source
info.content: Australian Bureau of Statistics – Regional Statistics by LGA 2017 http://stat.data.abs.gov.au/Index.aspx

members.name: Labour force participation
members.description: The labour force participation rate indicates the size of the labour force relative to the population in a region. This measure is defined as the total number of people in a region who are employed or actively looking for work and are available to work, expressed as a percentage of the population aged 15 years and over.

members.name: Own unincorporated business income
members.description: Own unincorporated business income is the profit or loss that accrues to owners of, or partners in, their own unincorporated businesses. Profit or loss is the value of the gross output of the enterprise after the deduction of operating expenses, including reportable superannuation contributions, depreciation and operating costs, but before income tax is taken out. Losses occur when operating expenses are greater than receipts and are treated as negative income.

members.name: Personal Income
members.description:
This dataset provides the median income for each LGA based on 2015-16FY tax return data supplied by the ATO to ABS. Total personal income includes employee income, own unincorporated business income, investment income, superannuation and annuities income. It should be noted that some income earners are not represented in these statistics because they did not submit a tax return. This coverage gap is likely to include many individuals who earned below the tax-free threshold and many Government benefit recipients, therefore providing an incomplete picture of low income earners. This is important to consider when comparing estimates in this dataset with distribution-based measures from other statistical collections.

The Gini coefficient is a summary indicator between 0 and 1 which measures the degree of inequality of total income within a region.

info.name: Source
info.content: Australian Bureau of Statistics – Regional Statistics by LGA 2017 http://stat.data.abs.gov.au/Index.aspx

members.name: Population Projections
members.description: Population projections provide a measure of the expected population growth trajectory for a region.

members.name: Selected pensions or allowances
members.description:
This indicator provides an estimate of the extent to which residents of a region are in receipt of government benefits. This indicator focuses on the main types of pensions and allowances which can represent the main source of income for a recipient.

Selected pensions include: Age Pension, Service Pensions, Carer Payment, Disability Support Pension, Newstart, Parenting Payment and Youth Allowance.

members.name: Single Parent Families
members.description: This indicator measures the proportion of dwellings with families which are single parent in a region. The distribution of single parent families in a region can provide useful contextual information on the demographic and socio-economic make-up of an area, as well as other trends such as the changing structure of families.

members.name: Socio-Economic Disadvantage
members.description: Socio-economic indexes for areas (SEIFA) is a suite of four summary measures that have been created from Census information. Every geographic area in Australia is given a SEIFA number which shows how relatively disadvantaged that area is compared with other areas in Australia. The SEIFA deciles distribute scores into ten equal groups. The lowest scoring 10% of areas are given a decile number of 1, the second-lowest 10% of areas are given a decile number of 2 and so on, up to the highest 10% of areas which are given a decile number of 10.

info.name: Source
info.content: Australian Bureau of Statistics – Regional Statistics by LGA 2017 http://stat.data.abs.gov.au/Index.aspx

members.name: Unemployment rate
members.description:
Small Area Labour Markets presents regional estimates of the unemployment rate for each of Australia’s 540 Local Government Areas (LGAs).

The estimates are smoothed using a four-quarter average to minimise the variability inherent in small area estimates. A description of the methodology used to prepare the estimates in this publication is presented in the Explanatory Notes.

Highly disaggregated estimates of the unemployment rate at the LGA level can display significant variability and should be viewed with caution. Quarter-to-quarter comparisons may not be indicative of actual movements in the labour market. It is therefore recommended that year-on-year comparisons be used.

info.name: Source
info.content:
Department of Jobs and Small Business - Small Area Labour Markets

https://www.jobs.gov.au/small-area-labour-markets-publication

members.name: Vocational or higher education qualifications
members.description: This indicator measures the proportion of people aged 25 to 64 years old with a vocational (Certificate III or above) or higher education qualification.

members.name: Young people earning or learning
members.description: This indicator measures the proportion of young people who are fully engaged in either work or study. This indicator includes people aged between 15 and 24 years of age studying full-time, employed full-time, and those who are studying part-time and are employed.

members.name: Youth unemployment rate
members.description: The youth unemployment rate is the percentage of people in the labour force aged 15 to 24 who are unemployed. It measures those young people who are ready to enter into paid work and have recently taken active steps to find a job.

members.name: Soil
members.description:
Soil particles can be categorised into three groups by the size of their particles. Sand particles are the largest at 0.5 to 2.0mm, silt particles are 0.05 and 0.0002mm in size and clay particles are the smallest at less than 0.0002mm. Most soils are a combination of the three different soil types, with different plants growing better in different types of soils. The National Drought Map displays soils data from the Australian Soil Resource Information System which can be used to determine the amount of sand, silt and clay in your soil at 6 different depth levels.

The soils dataset also contains:
  • Available water capacity - the maximum amount of plant-available water a soil can provide
  • Bulk density - an indicator of soil compaction
  • Depth of regolith - the unconsolidated, loose, heterogeneous superficial deposits covering solid rock
  • Depth of soil – a thin layer of mineral matter that normally contains organic material and is capable of supporting living plants
  • Effective cation exchange capacity (ECEC) - the total amount of exchangeable cations
  • Organic carbon - a measureable component of soil organic matter
  • Total nitrogen
  • Total phosphorus
  • ph in Calcium Chloride

members.name: Available Water Capacity
members.description:
Available water capacity is the maximum amount of plant-available water a soil can provide. The amount of water in soil is based on the amount rainfall, what proportion of rain infiltrates into the soil, and the soil's storage capacity. It is an indicator of a soil’s ability to retain water and make it sufficiently available for plant use. Water capacity is usually expressed as a volume fraction or percentage, or as a depth (in or cm).

Why it is important?
Soil is a major storage reservoir for water. Water availability is an important indicator because plant growth and soil biological activity depend on water for hydration and delivery of nutrients in solution. Runoff and leaching volumes are also determined by storage capacity and pore size distribution.

In areas where rain falls daily and supplies the soil with as much or more water than is removed by plants, available water capacity may be of little importance. However, in areas where plants remove more water than is supplied by precipitation, the amount of water held by the soil may be critical. Water held in the soil may be necessary to sustain plants between rainfall or irrigation events. By holding water for future use, soil buffers the plant – root environment against periods of water deficit.

What is this data used for? Available water capacity is used to develop water budgets, predict draughtiness, design and operate irrigation systems, design drainage systems, protect water resources, and predict yields.

Bulk Density (Whole Earth)
members.description:
Bulk density is an indicator of soil compaction. It is calculated as the dry weight of soil divided by its volume. This volume includes the volume of soil particles and the volume of pores among soil particles. It is typically expressed in g/cm3.

Bulk density is dependent on soil organic matter, soil texture, the density of soil mineral (sand, silt, and clay) and their packing arrangement. As a rule of thumb, most rocks have a density of 2.65 g/cm3 so ideally, a silt loam soil has 50% pore space and a bulk density of 1.33 g/cm3.

Why is it important?
Soils with a bulk density greater than 1.6g/cm3 may restrict the growth of roots.

Clay Content
members.description:
Clay is the inorganic fraction of soil with extremely fine particles of less than 0.0002mm. Clay may clump when wet to the point that the individual particles are not visible to the naked eye.

The space between the mineral particles, called the pore space, affects the amount of air and water that soil can hold. Different plants grow better in different types of soils, with some being well-adapted to clay soils.

info.name: Data Description
info.content:
Regolith is the unconsolidated, loose, heterogeneous superficial deposits covering solid rock.

What is the difference between soil and regolith?
Soil is a zone of plant growth and is a thin layer of mineral matter that normally contains organic material and is capable of supporting living plants. Regolith is inorganic and lies like a blanket over unfragmented rock.

members.name: Effective Cation Exchange Capacity
members.description:
The effective cation exchange capacity (ECEC) is defined as the total amount of exchangeable cations, which are mostly sodium, potassium, calcium and magnesium in non-acidic soils and bases plus aluminium in acidic soils. The concentration of cations are extracted using barium chloride (BaCl2) plus exchangeable H + Al. These are measured in millequivalents per 100 grams of soil.

What does ECEC represent?

A high CEC value (>25) is a good indicator that a soil has a high clay and/or organic matter content and can hold a lot of cations. A soil with a low CEC value (<5) is a good indication that a soil is sandy with little or no organic matter that cannot hold many cations.

members.name: Organic Carbon
members.description:
Soil organic carbon is a measureable component of soil organic matter. Organic matter makes up just 2–10% of most soil's mass and has an important role in the physical, chemical and biological function of agricultural soils. Organic matter contributes to nutrient retention and turnover, soil structure, moisture retention and availability, degradation of pollutants, and carbon sequestration.

How is soil organic carbon different to soil organic matter?
Soil organic carbon (SOC) refers only to the carbon component of organic compounds. Soil organic matter (SOM) is difficult to measure directly, so laboratories tend to measure and report SOC.

Why is organic carbon important in soil?
Higher soil organic carbon promotes soil structure or tilth, meaning there is greater physical stability. This improves soil aeration (oxygen in the soil) and water drainage and retention, and reduces the risk of erosion and nutrient leaching.

Sand Content
members.description: Sand particles are the largest soil particles at 0.5 to 2.0mm. Sand is a naturally occurring granular material composed of finely divided rock and mineral particles. A soil containing more than 85% sand-sized particles by mass is called sandy. Sand soils are often dry, nutrient deficient and fast-draining. The nutrient- and water-holding capacity of sand soils can be improved through adding organic material.

Silt Content
members.description: Silt is a solid, dust-like sediment that water, ice, and wind transport and deposit. Silt is made up of rock and mineral particles that are larger than clay but smaller than sand. Silt particles are between 0.05 and 0.0002mm in size and when dry, may feel similar to flour. Silt has a relatively limited surface area with little chemical activity. Soils high in silt may compact under heavy traffic. This affects the movement of air and water in the soil.

Total Nitrogen
members.description: The release of mineral nitrogen from decomposition of organic matter is a significant source of nitrogen for grain crops in Australia. Most nitrogen release from organic matter occurs during the growing season, providing a steady, continuous supply of nitrogen to the crop. This is because the microorganisms responsible for releasing nitrogen from organic matter require some soil moisture. When you have too much nitrogen in soil, your plants may look lush and green, but their ability to fruit and flower will be greatly reduced.

Total Phosphorus
members.description:
Phosphorus is essential for plant growth, but few Australian soils have enough phosphorus for sustained crop and pasture production. Complex soil processes influence the availability of phosphorus applied to the soil, with many soils able to absorb or ‘fix’ phosphorus, making it less available to plants. A soil’s ability to fix phosphorus must be measured when determining requirements for crops and pastures.

Phosphorus is one of the most critical and limiting nutrients in agriculture in NSW. Phosphorus fertiliser is best applied at seeding, however, only 5–30% of phosphorus applied as fertiliser is taken up by the plant in the year of application.
